metadata_frame: The following passage comes from Powers, Duties and Work of Game Wardens : a Handbook of Practical Information for Officers and Others Interested in the Enforcement of Fish and Game Laws, a handbook published in 1910 by Harry Chase, an American writer.
main_question:
But if a person has in his possession trout less than six inches long he is, all the time he has them in his possession, violating the provisions of 5275 P. S. Therefore, it follows that if the warden has reasonable cause to believe that a person has in his possession a trout less than six inches long he may, under the authority of Sec. 5271, arrest him without a warrant. The application of this law must be made in view of the nature of the crime itself, and in view of the means of securing evidence showing the commission of crime, [masked clause describing a cause or reason]. I believe that if the warden, disclosing his office, sees a person under such circumstances as to indicate that the person is in the possession of trout caught in the waters of this state, that is, if he sees him coming from a brook with a fish basket over his shoulder and a fish rod in his hand, he has the right to ask that person to show him the contents of the basket and to show him all the fish
in his possession.

Write a clause appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked clause describing a cause or reason]:
source_title: Powers, Duties and Work of Game Wardens : a Handbook of Practical Information for Officers and Others Interested in the Enforcement of Fish and Game Laws
answer_strings: for if the warden could not arrest a man personally until he was certain that he had in his possession trout less than six inches long it would practically nullify the law, for anyone breaking the law will naturally conceal his offense

for if the warden must arrest a man personally only when he is certain that he has in his possession trout over six inches long it would practically enforce the law, for anyone following the law will naturally reveal their compliance
for the officer as the prisoner's keeper
for sheriffs have such authority by statute to serve criminal process
if there is probable cause to suspect that the person has violated fishing regulations.
particularly when the suspect is in a location where fishing is prohibited or when his conduct indicates recent fishing activity, such as carrying a fish basket or fishing rod
passage: The application of this law must be made in view of the nature of the crime itself, and in view of the means of securing evidence showing the commission of crime, for if the warden could not arrest a man personally until he was certain that he had in his possession trout less than six inches long it would practically nullify the law, for anyone breaking the law will naturally conceal his offense.

main_question:
But anything which subjects a person to the actual control or will of another constitutes an arrest and imprisonment, whether it is physical control, locking the door of a room in which the arrested person is found, or a voluntary submission to words of arrest. An officer effects an arrest of a person whom he has authority to arrest, by laying his hand on him for the purpose of arresting him, though he may not succeed in stopping or holding him. (Mere words spoken to one are not an arrest of him; there must be something physical, [masked clause conceding a limit or exception]

though contact alone is insufficient for an arrest

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from Powers, Duties and Work of Game Wardens : a Handbook of Practical Information for Officers and Others Interested in the Enforcement of Fish and Game Laws, a handbook published in 1910 by Harry Chase, an American writer.
main_question:
(Extracts from a pamphlet)

By R. W. WILLIAMS, JR., 

Assistant, Biological Survey. For several hundred years the enforcement of criminal laws of all kinds in this country has been intrusted to sheriffs, constables, and police officers, and until the middle of the nineteenth century this method was considered satisfactory. [masked sentence describing a tension or contrast] The origin of the term "warden" in relation to game is somewhat obscure, but it was probably adopted in analogy to church and wood wardens in England, where the word first came into use.

Write a sentence appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked sentence describing a tension or contrast]:
source_title: Powers, Duties and Work of Game Wardens : a Handbook of Practical Information for Officers and Others Interested in the Enforcement of Fish and Game Laws
answer_strings: But with the growing demand for more stringent enactments for the preservation of game and the increasing complexity of statutes for this purpose it was found no longer practicable to include the burden of enforcing them among the duties devolving upon general officers, and their enforcement has consequently been intrusted to special officials, usually called game wardens.

But with the growing demand for more lenient enactments for the preservation of game and the decreasing complexity of statutes for this purpose it was found no longer practicable to exclude the burden of enforcing them among the duties devolving upon general officers, and their enforcement has consequently been intrusted to special officials, usually called game wardens.

However, it should be remembered that game laws and game wardens are of comparatively recent origin in the United States, and that only a short time ago the popular idea respecting fish and game was that wherever found they were almost as much the property of the individual citizen as the air we breathe.
However, this may be, a game warden is now generally understood to be an officer charged with the enforcement of laws for the protection of game and fish.
However, as society evolved and new challenges emerged, particularly with the rise of industrialization and urbanization, traditional law enforcement methods began to show limitations.

However, the protection of wildlife and game, unlike ordinary criminal statutes, demanded a specialized approach, as the traditional law‑enforcement bodies were ill‑prepared to address the unique challenges posed by poaching and the preservation of natural resources.
passage: But with the growing demand for more stringent enactments for the preservation of game and the increasing complexity of statutes for this purpose it was found no longer practicable to include the burden of enforcing them among the duties devolving upon general officers, and their enforcement has consequently been intrusted to special officials, usually called game wardens.

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from Powers, Duties and Work of Game Wardens : a Handbook of Practical Information for Officers and Others Interested in the Enforcement of Fish and Game Laws, a handbook published in 1910 by Harry Chase, an American writer.
main_question:
But the necessity for a guilty mind or criminal intent does not mean that it is necessary that the person doing the prohibited act be conscious that it is wrong, for, as we have said before, ignorance of the law excuses no one. [masked sentence describing an inference or effect]

Write a sentence appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked sentence describing an inference or effect]:
source_title: Powers, Duties and Work of Game Wardens : a Handbook of Practical Information for Officers and Others Interested in the Enforcement of Fish and Game Laws
answer_strings: Thus when the selling of adulterated milk is made a crime, ignorance that the milk sold is below the standard fixed by law is no defense.
Thus when the selling of pure milk is made a crime, knowledge that the milk sold is above the standard fixed by law is no defense.
Hence it is said that every crime, at least at common law, consists of two elements-the criminal act or omission, and the mental element commonly called the criminal intent.
Therefore, to make an arrest lawful, it is necessary that the person arrested should have notice that he is arrested by lawful authority.
This implies that even if someone is unaware of the moral implications of their actions, they can still be held liable for their deeds.
Therefore, a person may be held liable for a prohibited act even if he did not consciously recognize it as unlawful.
passage: Thus when the selling of adulterated milk is made a crime, ignorance that the milk sold is below the standard fixed by law is no defense.

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from Powers, Duties and Work of Game Wardens : a Handbook of Practical Information for Officers and Others Interested in the Enforcement of Fish and Game Laws, a handbook published in 1910 by Harry Chase, an American writer.
main_question:
THE WARDEN'S GENERAL MOVEMENTS 

Quite often we hear a warden complain that the regular violators in his territory keep so well posted on his general movements and plans from day to day that his success in apprehending them is thus seriously handicapped. This is true in many cases, [masked clause describing a tension or contrast]. It is the fate of all wardens, and the really clever ones are only stirred to increased efforts by this difficulty.

Write a clause appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked clause describing a tension or contrast]:
source_title: Powers, Duties and Work of Game Wardens : a Handbook of Practical Information for Officers and Others Interested in the Enforcement of Fish and Game Laws
answer_strings: but usually the warden is inclined to overestimate this obstacle
but usually the warden is inclined to underestimate this obstacle
but for general work and without local assistance and co-operation the shrewdest warden in the country will be an utter failure

however, the office of game warden is a difficult one to fill, and it is the duty of every good citizen to lend this important public servant every assistance and encouragement in the discharge of his duties
yet they find it equally difficult to keep their own movements from becoming predictable
yet the most seasoned wardens discover that this same vigilance often drives offenders into increasingly erratic and unpredictable patterns
passage: This is true in many cases, but usually the warden is inclined to overestimate this obstacle.

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from Powers, Duties and Work of Game Wardens : a Handbook of Practical Information for Officers and Others Interested in the Enforcement of Fish and Game Laws, a handbook published in 1910 by Harry Chase, an American writer.
main_question:
While one is conversing with the occupants of a camp his dog will be extremely busy searching every nook and corner for game or fish, and if there is any such there it is very certain to be brought to his master's attention by his faith-
ful dog, and the latter don't require any special training to render this service, either. It is his nature and instinct to do so. There is also a case where a warden's pointer dog discovered a large shipment of game birds in a box at a railway station. These birds were very cleverly secreted, but they could not escape the fine nose of the pointer and he "made game" as soon as he drew near them, [masked clause describing an inference or effect]. But there are "dogs and dogs.

Write a clause appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked clause describing an inference or effect]:
source_title: Powers, Duties and Work of Game Wardens : a Handbook of Practical Information for Officers and Others Interested in the Enforcement of Fish and Game Laws
answer_strings: so that his master was able to seize the game and apprehend the culprits
so that his master could not prevent the game from escaping nor catch the culprits
so valuable for their fur, are not subject of larceny."
so it is presumed in choosing a dog for an assistant the warden will choose wisely, with his special needs always in view
alerting the warden to their presence.
which promptly alerted the warden, resulting in the immediate seizure of the illegal shipment
passage: These birds were very cleverly secreted, but they could not escape the fine nose of the pointer and he "made game" as soon as he drew near them, so that his master was able to seize the game and apprehend the culprits.

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from Powers, Duties and Work of Game Wardens : a Handbook of Practical Information for Officers and Others Interested in the Enforcement of Fish and Game Laws, a handbook published in 1910 by Harry Chase, an American writer.
main_question:
When such is found, if a part of the deer carcass was missing, the warden will make all haste to procure a search warrant and search the place before the meat has been consumed. If the process of securing a search warrant requires too much valuable time, then he will attempt to enter the place without such warrant by subterfuge. This can often be done without the officer exceeding his authority. For instance, [masked clause describing a condition]. Or he may summon the inmates and request their permission to search the place, and may do so with the occupant's, or his agent's, consent.

Write a clause appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked clause describing a condition]:
source_title: Powers, Duties and Work of Game Wardens : a Handbook of Practical Information for Officers and Others Interested in the Enforcement of Fish and Game Laws
answer_strings: if he finds the doors or windows open and no one to answer his knock, he may enter
if he finds the doors and windows securely closed and someone promptly answers his knock, he should leave
if a part of the deer carcass was missing, the warden will make all haste to procure a search warrant and search the place before the meat has been consumed
if the offender escapes and takes refuge in his own or another house, the officer is justified in breaking doors to retake him
for example if the wardens have reasonable cause to believe that evidence of illegal activity is being destroyed
if the carcass is located in a private dwelling where the occupant has given prior consent or is absent, the warden may lawfully enter without a warrant by subterfuge
